Award.AwardTitle: Expanding the Use of Liquid Chromatography Through Active Temperature Control
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation. Professor Stephen Weber and colleagues at the University of Pittsburgh address limitations of liquid chromatography. The team is improving the ability of liquid chromatography techniques to distinguish one substance from another, as well as improving the ability to measure trace concentrations in a variety of samples. Chromatography is based on the principle of partitioning, the tendency of a substance to prefer an oily substance to water-based solution. The outcomes of this project include obtaining more and better information from samples with lower cost and lower environmental burden than has been previously realized. Collaborations with scientists in the fields of proteomics (for example, health, pharmaceuticals, and biochemistry research) and two-dimensional liquid chromatography (for example, pharmaceuticals, chemical industry, agriculture, and the environment) demonstrate the effectiveness of the project goals. The broader impacts are evidenced in that improvements in chromatographic processes that are useful across many fields and applications. Liquid chromatography is used in virtually every industry, for example, environmental, pharmaceutical, nutritional, forensic, toxicology, polymers, chemicals, and cosmetics. A Girl Scout merit badge project is also being developed by Dr. Weber to explore chromatography methods and its uses.

The project uses temperature control of the column to achieve greater solute focusing and to control retention in a predictable way. Retention enthalpies, which control the sensitivity of a particular compound to changes in temperature, are determined for a number of related organic compounds. These data are used to determine molecular fragment enthalpies. The temperature dependence of the retention of novel compounds are then predicted. Software to predict chromatographic behavior in the face of changing column temperature aids in chromatographic method development. The temperature control, when used to aid solute focusing, significantly improves concentration detection limits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chromatography is an analytical measurement tool that allows industry, healthcare, environmental organizations, military, police, and scientists to determine what chemicals are in natural or synthetic materials including solids, liquids, and gases. It is widely and successfully applied because it is eminently flexible. The general approach can be adapted to almost any question of, “What is the composition of this stuff?” This project has been focused on increasing the power of using temperature in so-called liquid chromatography, one branch of chromatography. Chromatography separates the components of a small sample of a mixture by passing the mixture through a tube, called a “column”, containing a porous medium, called a “stationary phase”. In liquid chromatography, the mixture is introduced as a solution and carried through the column dissolved in a liquid called the “mobile phase”. The individual components of the mixture spend time in both mobile and stationary phases thus establishing an average velocity through the column. In an ideal circumstance, all the components have different average velocities and thus come out of the column at different times. The components are typically detected by one of many electronic means so that each component’s passage out of the column is registered in sequence. The detection is quantitative, so how much there is of each component can be established. The problem is that the velocities of some components may be the same. The only way to make them different is to alter the conditions in the column. Our rationale was that it is very easy to change the temperature of the critical component in a chromatography system, the column which includes the mobile and stationary phases as well as the components of the sample, in principle, but in practice it is not easy, and changing temperatures is slow. Thus, our laboratory developed several approaches to improving this situation.

We used thermoelectric devices for rapid heating and cooling. This is effective in obtaining more information from a sample in a shorter time than possible in the past. We also created the means to program the temperature in specific ways to achieve improved separations. Also, controlling temperature permits samples to be concentrated during introduction into the column. This makes the components more concentrated on the column than they are in the sample and thus easier to detect and measure. This is particularly important when seeking to detect trace components of a mixture.

The approach of using temperature more wisely led to two realizations. One is that the stationary phases available may not survive the temperature extremes that are accessible with our devices. The other is that the available theory did not permit accurate modeling of the effect of temperature on liquid chromatographic separations. Thus, we developed several stable stationary phases based on a very simple chemical reaction known as the thiol-yne reaction. These stationary phases were not only stable but had properties different from other phases making them useful in general. We also examined three accepted mathematical models of how liquid chromatography works. We made more than 6000 individual measurements of the average velocities of ~ 100 compounds at ~ 5 temperatures and ~ 12 mobile phase compositions. We repeated these measurements four times for a total of over 25 000 measurements at different mobile phase compositions and temperatures. We found that one particular model was quite good. Thus, with a little information about the nature of the components being separated predictions could be made about how to alter the mobile phase and temperature to achieve the best separation.
